title: Exploring the hypothesis that olive oil is healthy
content: Peter and Bob take a deep dive into olive oil. They explore the history of olive oil, discuss observational data that led to the hypothesis that olive oil is a healthier alternative to many other fats.

title: Comparing olive oil to the makeup of other common oils
content: Peter and Bob discuss the three broad categories of fats: SFA, MUFA, and PUFA. They compare olive oil to the makeup of other common oils.

title: Defining “extra virgin” olive oil, what to look for when purchasing, and Peter’s favorite brand
content: Peter and Bob explain the classification of olive oil types —including what to look for in a high-quality “extra virgin” olive oil. They also share Peter’s favorite brand.

title: Zone 5 training: Peter’s approach to zone 5 training, and other anaerobic training protocols
content: Peter and Bob discuss zone 5 training, including Peter’s approach to zone 5 training, and other anaerobic training protocols.

content: Peter and Bob discuss the advantages of using a standing desk compared to sitting.

title: Lactate meters and strips
content: Peter and Bob discuss lactate meters and strips.

content: Peter and Bob discuss electrolyte supplementation during fasting and keto, and why uric acid may increase.

title: The usefulness of massage guns, foam rollers, and professional massage for muscle pain and tightness

title: The Perceived Benefit of Olive Oil
content: We always hear that olive oil is really healthy for us—that it’s heart-protective—Is it truly cardio-protective? So where does this perceived benefit of olive oil come from? First and foremost, it stems primarily from the observational data of the mediterranean diet.

title: The Early History of Olive Oil and the Mediterranean Diet
content: Background on the idea that olive oil is healthy. Ancel Keys was the first to champion the diet in the 1970s and promoted heavily in the 1990s. Keys believed that food sources that were high in saturated fats were the problem, whereas those that were high in polyunsaturated and monounsaturated fats were going to be cardio-protective.

title: The three broad categories of fats
content: The three broad categories of fats: SFA, MUFA, and PUFA. Saturated fats (SFA) are “saturated” with hydrogen. Monounsaturated fats (MUFA) have the same long carbon chain as SFA, but there’s one double bond in a monounsaturated fatty acid. Polyunsaturated fats (PUFA) have two or more double bonds. The nomenclature is important, says Peter.

title: Exploring the hypothesis that olive oil is healthy
content: There was the observation that populations that consumed high amounts of olive oil and other monounsaturated fats had better health. First, less saturated fats. Secondly, more oleic acid. Thirdly, less PUFA. Fourth, substituting olive oil for carbohydrates in the short-term increased HDL cholesterol without increasing LDL cholesterol.

title: Benefits of Olive Oil Consumption
content: A 2014 meta-analysis concluded that an elevated consumption of olive oil is associated with reduced risk of all-cause mortality, cardiovascular events and stroke. When comparing the top versus bottom third of MUFA, olive oil, oleic acid, and MUFA:SFA ratio, the results indicate an overall risk reduction of all-cause mortality (11%), cardiovascular mortality (12%), cardiovascular events (9%), and stroke (17%).

title: Issues with the Meta-Analysis
content: The large majority of this analysis was done by looking at observational data which rely on retrospective questionnaires. Another huge issue is healthy user bias.

title: Lyon Diet Heart Study
content: The study reported benefits from a mediterranean diet (which generally is high in olive oil). Incidence of MACE after about 4 years was lower in those assigned a MeDiet (~67% relative reduction; ~6% annual absolute reduction) compared to those assigned an AHA prudent diet. All-cause mortality was also lower (~56% relative reduction; ~1% annual absolute reduction).

title: PREDIMED Study
content: This was a primary prevention study that was cleverly designed. The study was halted after about five years because the protective benefit of the two mediterranean arms was so high. In short, despite some flaws, the PREDIMED provided reinforcement to this idea that was shown in the Lyon diet heart study along with all of the observational data.

title: Overall Thoughts on Mediterranean Diet
content: Suffice it to say that there seems to be reasonable evidence that a mediterranean diet is a good diet in the sense that it preserves the obvious features of a good diet (no processed foods, low in sugars, etc.). In fact, pretty much all “diets” advocate for less processed foods and refined carbohydrates/added sugar.

title: Different diets for different purposes
content: Peter Attia says that different diets may be required for different purposes such as maintenance, prevention, or treatment. For instance, a Mediterranean diet may be a great strategy for prevention, but someone with NAFLD, NASH, or type two diabetes may require a different strategy that restricts fructose and calories significantly and/or one that restricts carbohydrates, respectively.

title: Comparison of fat composition in various oils
content: Olive oil is mainly composed of oleic acid, a MUFA, and is about 75% MUFA. Soybean oil and corn oil, which are commonly found in processed foods, are about 24% MUFA and 29% MUFA, respectively. Lard is about 46% MUFA, 42% SFA, and about 10% PUFA. Coconut oil is the one that’s mostly saturated fat, about 91%. High-oleic sunflower is 86% and high-oleic canola is 76%.

title: Defining extra virgin olive oil
content: Extra virgin olive oil must meet certain legal requirements set by the International Olive Council, including certain tastes and chemical properties. The olives must be healthy and expertly picked, and milled within 24 hours of the harvest to preserve their flavors and avoid spoilage. There are particular taste profiles that determine whether an olive oil is extra virgin or not.

title: Things to look for in a quality olive oil
content: When looking for quality olive oil, one should consider the cost, harvest date, smell and taste, descriptors, place of production, and how it's bottled. A good olive oil is expensive, has a harvested date within 18 months, smells fresh like grass or something fruity, has a bitter, peppery taste that bites the back of the throat, and is not described as 'pure' or 'light'. The label should tell you where that olive oil was produced, and it should be in a dark cool place to preserve the olive oil.

title: Brand Peter likes
content: Peter likes Kosterina olive oil. He stumbled upon a store that only sold olive oil and was blown away at the strength of the taste of some of these oils. Many of them had that peppery bitter taste in the back of the throat. The oils were also 'comically pricey' says Peter. This experience made Peter think: 'I need to up my game a little bit on olive oil because if there is any benefit to this, I want to make sure I’m getting it.'

title: Peter’s approach with his patients
content: Peter believes that no less than 50% of a person's fat intake should be monounsaturated, and ideally closer to 60%. Olive oil, macadamia nuts, and avocados are ideal sources for those monounsaturated fats. 'Those become a great way to achieve your MUFA goals, and that’s part of what we consider the appropriate distribution of fat.' —Peter Attia

title: Olive oil made from an 'early harvest' may be better
content: Olive oils made from an 'early harvest' may be better because they have more monounsaturated fats than polyunsaturated fats. The oleic acid within the olive oil can vary from 55% to 83% of the total fat in the olive oil, depending on the ripeness of the olive.

title: Zone 5 training
content: Peter’s approach to zone 5 training, and other anaerobic training protocols. Peter’s zone 5 protocol. On his stairmaster: One time per week using a stairmaster. 4 minute pattern: 3 minutes of zone 2. 1 minute at his VO2 max. Repeat for 20-30 minutes. He also does zone 5 on his bike: Four minutes at 125% of FTP (functional threshold power). Followed by four minutes recovery. A one to one work/rest at a lower intensity than the 3 to 1 one rest to work that described on the stairmaster. “My view is most people spend too much time there and not enough time in zone 2.” —Peter Attia

title: Olive oil composition
content: Considering that oleic is basically 99% of the MUFA in olive oil, you could have it be as low as 50% of total fat and as high as 70+%. The linoleic acid ranges from about 3.5% to 21% of olive oil. During the ripening process, the more ripe the fruit, the ratio of MUFA to PUFA falls — So, the polyunsaturated fat content is greater. Basically, the earlier you harvest, the unripe olive is going to give you the highest amount of oleic acid and the least amount of linoleic acid. “If you buy the argument that oleic is good, which I buy, and if you buy the argument that linoleic is suboptimal, which I’m not sure I buy, the earlier is better.” —Peter Attia

title: Tabata workouts
content: Let’s look at tabata workouts: Consider two variants of Tabata: i) The 20:10 (20 sec spring with 10 sec recovery) and ii) the 10:20 (10 sec sprint with 20 sec recovery). Air bikes are a great tool for doing these types of workouts. You can go so much harder for the 10:20 than the 20:10. The 20:10 is generally favored because that’s the one that was studied by Izumi Tabata (the guy who wrote the papers) and Koichi Irisawa (the guy who actually developed the workout protocol). The problem with a “20:10 Tabata” is whether consciously or subconsciously you’re actually pacing yourself to complete it.

title: Update on Peter’s book
content: About 12 months ago, Peter decided to change publishers. He is currently shopping around for a new publisher. This has pushed back the release of his book. The good news is that he does have a manuscript ready to be reviewed by an editor. Peter’s hope is that the book hits shelves in January of 2022.

title: All-out performance
content: Basically, the limits of human performance in terms of “going all out” is about 10 seconds (despite what your spin class instructor might tell you). You only need to look at the difference between a 100-meter and a 200-meter sprint. So, take the best explosive athletes on the planet — even by the time Usain Bolt is running the 200m, he is slowing down in the second half of that race. The force with which he’s able to hit the ground in the second half of that race is slower. The 100-meter race is basically a 10-second race is about the true limit of what “all out” means.

title: Peter's stairmaster
content: The stairmaster Peter uses is a series of eight-inch steps that roll up and down (like an escalator). The higher the intensity you set it, the less resistance is in those steps and the faster you have to go to not fall off the back. If Peter sets it to 8 METs, there’s actually quite a bit of resistance so he can step quite slowly without falling off. But when set to 20 METs, it feels like there’s no resistance and he’s running up the stairs to not get thrown off the back.

title: Tabata Protocols
content: Tabata protocols were devised in the early 1990s by Kouichi Irisawa, head coach of the Japanese national speed skating team. Izumi Tabata was hired by Kouichi to test the effectiveness of the interval training program.

title: Advantages of Using a Standing Desk
content: Standing engages more muscles than sitting, including paraspinal muscles, abdominal muscles, obliques, and transversalis. Walking is preferred to sitting because it forces you to actively engage muscles that prevent you from a bad postural position. Peter avoids the issues from sitting by practicing sitting in a very actively engaged way and by constantly getting up and moving around.

title: Lactate Meters and Strips
content: Peter currently uses the Lactate Plus by Nova to measure lactate levels to confirm zone two after exercise. The Lactate Plus is not cheap, and the cost of the strips are very expensive at ~$4 each. There may be a more affordable device + strips out there but Peter can’t speak to that. Peter personally does the lactate test every single time he does his zone 2 workouts.

title: Electrolyte Supplementation During Fasting and Keto
content: Salt supplementation in keto is really not necessary for everyone, and personally for Peter, he doesn’t find it necessary during his brief periods of keto (and even when he’s short periods of fasting). During the longer fasts, Peter does need sodium, but that’s because he’s not eating food and he’s trying to just get sodium back to normal levels. In keto, he does not supplement sodium at all, but he does supplement magnesium.

title: Uric Acid and Fasting
content: Peter discusses the increase in uric acid during fasting and ketosis. He suggests that uric acid and BHB may be competing for the same transporters in the kidney, or that uric acid is going up due to the turnover of DNA during autophagy.

title: Massage Guns, Foam Rollers, and Professional Massage
content: Peter compares the effectiveness of massage guns, foam rollers, and professional massage for muscle pain and tightness. He cautions that massage guns can be harmful if used too aggressively and may not address the underlying problem. He suggests that a better course of action may be gentle massage work coupled with muscle relaxants and fixing the underlying problem.
